Irish forestry will also have to change. We must move away from upland, mono-culture & clear-fell plantations to allowing trees re-seed naturally in ‚Äòcontinuous cover‚Äô forests and promote the new agroforestry options ‚Å¶@pippa_hackett‚Å© is introducing. ‚Å¶@IrishRainforest‚Å© https://t.co/8m9cMbWE5L

And how will we manage Rhododendron and other invasive species, which are crowding out the more biodiverse, carbon intensive temperate rainforest alternative? We need to pay a new generation of farmers & foresters for this vital task, as stewards of our land and natural systems. https://t.co/LOSjQZtk1Q

The challenges are also the same. How do we avoid wild deer or grazing sheep taking every budding sapling, which prevents the forest regenerating & stops the creation of a more diverse ground cover. It‚Äôs one of the issues the ongoing national land use review will have to address. https://t.co/PiMNPpTXoj

In Donegal the same conditions exist to re-establish temperate rainforests from the tiny fragments of diverse woodlands that remain.
